RT @NCETM: Primary teachers ‚Äì planning training for the new school year? Our ready-to-go PowerPoint on how to use the new DfE Mathematics g‚Ä¶
RT @perksofteaching: @Mr_K_Teacher Really eye-opening reading this! I‚Äôve always thought being a teacher from a ‚Äòdisadvantaged background‚Äô m‚Ä¶
@MissBrownYork83 I think @MrBKing1988 does.

I certainly don't know all the answers but do know that if I hadn't become a teacher I wouldn't be the person I am now.  I am not saying I am anything special as a person but I really feel that I am a better version of myself than I was.

I think it is important that children with school experience like mine find very real opportunities to mix with society. By this, I don't mean a school charity trip to Africa etc. I mean regular opportunities to mix and be part of their communities.
I don't know that point I am really trying to make other than the fact that I was just a kid who attended a certain school. To some extent that defined me, in ways good and bad.
It totally changed the way I see the world and made me hugely reconsider the things that I value as important.

Becoming a teacher really changed everything for me. Spending time around wonderful colleagues, children and families from a range of backgrounds opened my eyes ages 26 in a way they had never been opened before.

This wasn't intentional but more down to similar life experiences, hobbies etc. I was by no means the most academic but had a certain level of innate entitlement that I am ashamed of looking back on things.

Going to university was the first time that I was really in an environment for a prolonged period of time with people from a range of school backgrounds. Again though, a natural affiliation to those from a similar schooling to myself occurred.
I played club sport with children from a range of schools but there always seemed to be a bit of a social divide, I'm unclear if this was intentional or unintentional but it happened.

Without realising, a level of 'snobbery' certainly crept into my personality. Attending a private school subtly reinforces a warped idea of social standing and it is very easy for such attitudes to be formed without any such intention.

I experienced privilege without really appreciating the position I was in. Naturally, my friends were those in my school circle and other children I mixed with playing county sports etc tended to be in a similar position to myself.

I loved my time at school and always speak extremely highly of it. It really did an awful lot for me as a person in a very positive way. Academically it pushed me to be the best I could be and gave me sporting experiences that others dream of.

extra curricular activities, go on some fantastic trips, attend classes of smaller sized (I accept this is negligible in terms of impact but certainly helped me with ADHD). I accept that being able to attend this school gave me opportunities that others perhaps didn't have.

Attending Reigate Grammar is something that I have always considered myself very fortunate to have been able to do. I don't mean this in a way that demeans state schools in any sense but do consider myself fortunate to have been able to experience some unbelievable

I have seen quite a few disparaging comments about independent/ fee paying schools on Twitter historically but this has really heightened of late. As someone who attended one of these schools myself, I thought I would give my 'two pennies worth'.

He will likely be the ODI/ T20 Captain soon anyway and a white ball only approach could benefit that. I‚Äôd just like to see him given the summer and then if he hasn‚Äôt drastically improves draw a line

@cricket_badger I am of the strong believe that Bairstow can no longer score FC runs like he did. He completely changed his technique to become a world class white ball player. Stays leg side and throws hands. Bairstow historically yes but not now unless he hugely revamped his method.
@cricket_badger I am not suggesting his keeping is the best around but it is a lot better than people credit him for in my opinion.

@cricket_badger I accept that he has played 42 games. But in that time he has batted between 5-8. Kept and not kept. Played in a team with a very shaky top order and still produced reasonably ok figures. I just feel he may be best set up to succeed now and would like to see if he actually can.

@cricket_badger If after the summer he has proven to be the same guy we have seen I would absolutely accept that it is time to move on. I just think if he is dropped now then that is likely the end Test wise for him and would like to confidently say we have seen what he can do.

@cricket_badger Do you honestly not believe he could be better than he has shown? I fully appreciate your points made about his FC stats but feel he has genuinely developed a lot. Yesterday was good but a small sample. I would just like to see him have th me summer now we look more solid up top.
@cricket_badger I can just see a case for giving Buttler the summer. I can see a compelling case for Foakes and Bracey but I worry it could be a case of the grass always being greener.

@cricket_badger We can select samples from anywhere though. In 2020 he has scored 35, 9 and 40. Now whilst I‚Äôm not suggesting he has set the world alight, these aren‚Äôt scores that shout for a dropping.

@cricket_badger It isn‚Äôt that simple. But considering the bar for what success is seems unclear and the cultural value added is seemingly strong I can see the reason they aren‚Äôt rushing to change things.
@cricket_badger The top order is now looking more solid. Surely that increases the opportunities for Buttler to come in and play ‚Äòhis way‚Äô, rather than often coming in trying to salvage.

@cricket_badger But if Bairstow and Buttler score similarly now (Bairstow pre ODI success is a man altogether different FC batsman to now). Surely the argument for Bairstow is gone. Do you believe Buttler can do better than he already has in Teat cricket? Is how he has done actually not enough?

@cricket_badger What would a reasonable average be? There aren‚Äôt many keepers at round the world averaging 40+ in Test cricket at the moment. Buttler‚Äôs keeping has generally been very strong. If Foakes can genuinely match Buttler runs wise then I see the case..

@cricket_badger Good man. Now I totally appreciate the circumstances that Paine came back into the Aus side. If we are to take it as gospel that Buttler and Paine both add value to their teams in leadership and culture that perhaps compensate for their averages...
